trial_identification.studytitle: The Clinical Characteristics of Children with Generalised Joint Hypermobility and thier Relationship to Adverse Outcomes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: An observational study of the Clinical Characteristics of Children with Generalised Joint Hypermobility and thier Relationship to Adverse Outcomes

conditions.healthcondition: Joint Hypermobility Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (hypermobile type)

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other human genetics and inherited disorders

interventions.interventions: Observational study of natural history of pain, soft tissue injuries and fatigue symptoms as well as multisystemic involvement and function over 5 years. Main exposure is beighton score >=4/9 main outcome is disability measured by participation in physical activity, 6 minute walk test and HRQOL
interventions.comparator: general population - age matched from SPANS (booth et al 2004)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Disability function - mobility from 6 minute walk test participation - self reported physical activity questionnaire global wellbeing - health related quality of life from Peds QL

secondaryOutcome.outcome: fatigue as a result of condition from fatigue module Peds QL
pain as a result of condition from pain module Peds QL (Paediatric Quality of Life Inventory) and VAS (visual analogue scales)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Beighton Hypermobility Score of 4 or more of 9

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Arthritis Australia Level 2/255 Broadway GLEBE NSW 2037

othercollaborator.othercollaboratoraddress: Discipline of Biomedical Science, School of Medical Sciences, Sydney Medical School THE UNIVERSITY OF SYDNEY L122, Cumberland Campus C42 East St (PO Box 170) Lidcombe NSW 1825

THE UNIVERSITY OF SYDNEY L122, Cumberland Campus C42 East St (PO Box 170) Lidcombe NSW 1825

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Longitudinal Cohort study of outcomes in children with Joint hypermobility and the relationships between signs and symptoms, function, participation and outcomes.
ethicsAndSummary.publication:
Tofts LJ, Elliott EJ, Munns C, Pacey V, Sillence DO. The Differential diagnosis of hypermobility a review of the literature Paed Rheum 2009 7(1)
Pacey V, Adams RD, Tofts L, Munns CF, Nicholson LL. Joint hypermobility syndrome subclassification in paediatrics: a factor analytic approach. Archives of disease in childhood. Jan 2015;100(1):8-13.
Pacey V, Tofts L, Adams RD, Munns CF, Nicholson LL. Quality of life prediction in children with joint hypermobility syndrome. J Paediatr Child Health. 2015 Jan 26. doi: 10.1111/jpc.12826.
Pacey V, Tofts L, Wesley A, Collins F, Singh-Grewal D. Joint hypermobility syndrome: A review for clinicians. J Paediatr Child Health. 2014 Oct 7. doi: 10.1111/jpc.12731
